questions.stem: Hyperinsulinemia‑associated laminitis (HAL) is best described as:

options.label: A
options.text: A form of infectious laminitis caused by bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: Laminitis associated with persistently high blood insulin concentrations

options.label: C
options.text: Laminitis caused solely by excessive exercise on hard ground

options.label: D
options.text: A congenital deformity of the distal limb

questions.explanation: Hyperinsulinemia‑associated laminitis (HAL) refers to laminitis caused by persistently high blood insulin concentrations, as seen in EMS and other endocrine disorders. It is not primarily infectious (A), due to concussion alone (C), or a congenital deformity (D).

questions.stem: Equine metabolic syndrome (EMS) shows a strong breed predilection in which of the following?
questions.explanation: Paso Finos are specifically highlighted as a breed with a predilection for EMS, along with other easy‑keeper breeds. Standardbreds, Thoroughbreds, and Arabians (A, C, D) are less classically associated.

questions.stem: The cornerstone of treatment for equine metabolic syndrome (EMS) is:
questions.explanation: Dietary management (reducing nonstructural carbohydrates, controlling caloric intake, and promoting weight loss) is the cornerstone of EMS treatment. Antibiotics (A), long‑term steroids (B), and high‑grain diets (D) are inappropriate.

questions.stem: Equine Cushing’s disease in horses is also known as:
questions.explanation: Equine Cushing’s disease is more correctly termed pituitary pars intermedia dysfunction (PPID). It is distinct from EMS (A), EIPH (C), and RAO (D).

questions.stem: The primary cause of PPID (Cushing’s disease) in horses is:

options.label: A
options.text: Overactivity of one part of the pituitary gland due to loss of dopaminergic inhibition

questions.explanation: PPID is caused by overactivity of part of the pituitary gland, usually due to loss of dopaminergic inhibition from the hypothalamus, leading to hormone overproduction. Primary adrenal or thyroid disease (B, C) and diet alone (D) are not the primary causes.

questions.stem: Enlargement of the pituitary gland in PPID most commonly results from:

options.label: B
options.text: Damage to inhibitory nerves from the hypothalamus

questions.explanation: Damage to hypothalamic dopaminergic nerves removes inhibition of the pars intermedia, allowing it to enlarge and become overactive. Immune, bacterial, or parasitic causes (A, C, D) are not the main mechanisms.

questions.stem: Which type of diet should be AVOIDED in horses with Cushing’s disease (PPID) or EMS?
questions.explanation: Horses with PPID or EMS should not receive high‑sugar/high‑starch diets, which worsen insulin dysregulation and laminitis risk. Low‑NSC forage and high‑fiber diets (A, B, D) are preferred.

questions.stem: “Rain rot” in horses is more correctly termed:
questions.explanation: Rain rot (or rain scald) is dermatophilosis, a superficial skin infection caused by Dermatophilus congolensis. Dermatophytosis (A) refers to ringworm, and the other options (C, D) are unrelated skin diseases.

questions.stem: The causative agent of rain rot (rain scald) in horses is:
questions.explanation: Dermatophilus congolensis is the causative agent of rain rot in horses. Trichophyton and Microsporum (A, D) cause ringworm, and Staphylococcus (B) is not the primary etiologic agent here.

questions.stem: When hair is plucked from lesions of rain rot, the appearance is often described as:
questions.explanation: When crusts and hair are plucked in rain rot, they often come off in clumps resembling “paint brush” lesions. The other descriptors (B–D) refer to different lesion patterns.

questions.stem: On cytology or histopathology, Dermatophilus organisms are classically described as:

options.label: B
options.text: Railroad track or ladder‑like coccoid chains

questions.explanation: Dermatophilus organisms appear as “railroad track” or ladder‑like branching coccoid chains on cytology/histology. Grape‑like clusters (A) describe staphylococci, whereas fungi and yeast (C, D) look different.

questions.stem: A commonly recommended topical agent for treating rain rot in horses is:
questions.explanation: Chlorhexidine‑based antiseptics (and similar medicated shampoos) are commonly used topical treatments for rain rot. Plain water (B), mineral oil (C), and paraffin (D) are not standard therapies.

questions.stem: The best way to prevent spread of ringworm (dermatophytosis) between horses is:

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding shared grooming equipment such as combs and brushes

options.label: D
options.text: Turning horses out in the rain

questions.explanation: Avoiding shared grooming equipment (combs, brushes, tack) is a key measure to prevent transmission of ringworm. Bathing (A), diet (C), or weather exposure (D) do not specifically prevent spread.

questions.stem: Ringworm in horses typically damages which part of the skin?

options.label: C
options.text: Superficial keratinized layers of the skin and hair follicles

questions.explanation: Ringworm is a superficial fungal infection affecting the keratinized layers of the skin and hair follicles. It does not usually involve deep dermis, hooves, or muscle (A, B, D).

questions.stem: Equine melanomas are MOST commonly found in:
questions.explanation: Melanomas are particularly common in grey horses, especially as they age. Other coat colors (A, C, D) are less predisposed.

questions.stem: Typical locations for melanomas in grey horses include:

options.label: B
options.text: Perineum and base of the tail

questions.explanation: Common locations for melanomas in grey horses include the perineum and base of the tail, as well as the parotid region and lips. The other sites (A, C, D) are less typical.

questions.stem: The gold standard diagnostic test for equine sarcoids is:
questions.explanation: Histopathology of a biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing sarcoids. Cytology, culture, or imaging alone (A, B, D) cannot reliably distinguish sarcoids from other tumors.

questions.stem: Which of the following is a commonly used treatment approach for equine melanomas?

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical excision and/or medical therapy such as cimetidine

options.label: D
options.text: No treatment; melanomas should never be removed

questions.explanation: Treatment of equine melanomas often includes surgical excision and/or medical therapy such as cimetidine or intralesional chemotherapy. Antibiotics alone (A), steroids (C), or no treatment (D) are not appropriate in most cases.

questions.stem: Theiler’s disease in horses is classically associated with:

options.label: A
options.text: Recent administration of equine‑origin biologic products (e.g., tetanus antitoxin)

questions.explanation: Theiler’s disease (acute hepatic necrosis) is classically associated with recent administration of equine‑origin biologic products such as tetanus antitoxin or plasma. Moldy corn, protozoal infection, or copper deficiency (B–D) are not the hallmark associations.

questions.stem: Common bacterial causes of cholangiohepatitis in horses include:
questions.explanation: E. coli and Klebsiella are common bacterial causes of cholangiohepatitis in horses. Other combinations listed (B–D) involve different pathogens.

questions.stem: A useful biochemical indicator for diagnosing cholangiohepatitis in horses is:
questions.explanation: Elevated gamma‑glutamyl transferase (GGT) is a useful indicator of biliary disease, including cholangiohepatitis, in horses. Elevated CK, decreased AST, or low ALP (A, C, D) are not characteristic.

questions.stem: Tyzzer’s disease in foals is caused by:
questions.explanation: Tyzzer’s disease in foals is caused by Clostridium piliforme, an obligate intracellular, Gram‑negative, spore‑forming bacterium. Other clostridia (A, C, D) cause different diseases.

questions.stem: The main reservoir hosts of Eastern and Western equine encephalitis viruses (EEEV and WEEV) are, respectively:
questions.explanation: Birds are the main reservoir for EEEV, and rodents are important for WEEV. Reversing this (A) or using other species (C, D) is incorrect.

questions.stem: Pregnant mares should be vaccinated against tetanus:
questions.explanation: Pregnant mares are typically boosted for tetanus 4–6 weeks prior to parturition to ensure good colostral antibody transfer. Earlier, later, or wound‑only vaccination schedules (A, C, D) do not meet this goal.

questions.stem: Approximate recovery time for horses that survive tetanus is:
questions.explanation: Recovery from tetanus, when it occurs, can take around 6 weeks due to slow neuronal recovery and muscle remodeling. Shorter time frames (A, B) or much longer (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: The gold standard test for diagnosing rabies in animals is:

options.label: B
options.text: Direct fluorescent antibody test (FAT) on brain tissue

questions.explanation: The direct fluorescent antibody test (FAT) on brain tissue is the gold standard for rabies diagnosis. Serology, CSF analysis, or blood PCR alone (A, C, D) are not definitive.

questions.stem: Which of the following structures is NOT part of the equine navicular apparatus?
questions.explanation: The superficial digital flexor tendon is not part of the navicular apparatus. The navicular bone, DDFT, navicular bursa, and associated ligaments (A–C) are components.

questions.stem: In the treatment of osteoarthritis, hyaluronic acid is used primarily to:

options.label: B
options.text: Lubricate the joint and improve synovial fluid quality

questions.explanation: Intra‑articular hyaluronic acid improves lubrication and synovial fluid quality in osteoarthritic joints. It does not directly kill bacteria, stimulate bone growth, or replace menisci (A, C, D).

questions.stem: In exertional rhabdomyolysis (“tying‑up”), which serum enzymes are typically elevated?
questions.explanation: CK and AST are typically elevated in exertional rhabdomyolysis due to muscle cell damage. Other enzyme combinations (A, C, D) are more associated with hepatic or pancreatic disease.

questions.stem: The presence of coffee‑colored or dark brown urine in a horse after exertion is MOST consistent with:
questions.explanation: Coffee‑colored urine after exertion indicates myoglobinuria from muscle breakdown. Hematuria, bilirubinuria, or normal urine (A, C, D) are different conditions.

questions.stem: The gold standard test for Equine Infectious Anemia (EIA) is:

options.label: B
options.text: Agar Gel Immunodiffusion (AGID or Coggins test)

questions.explanation: The AGID (Coggins) test is the gold standard for Equine Infectious Anemia. ELISA (A) is a screening test; HI and Western blot alone (C, D) are not the primary confirmatory tests.

questions.stem: Purpura hemorrhagica in horses is associated with immune complexes primarily involving:
questions.explanation: Purpura hemorrhagica is linked to IgA–SeM immune complexes that deposit in vessel walls, triggering vasculitis. Other immunoglobulin/antigen combinations (A, C, D) are not characteristic.

questions.stem: The most pathogenic equine gastrointestinal helminth is:
questions.explanation: Strongylus vulgaris is considered the most pathogenic equine GI helminth due to its arterial migration and thromboembolic potential. Cyathostomins, Parascaris, and tapeworms (A, C, D) are important but less individually pathogenic.

questions.stem: The squamous (nonglandular) region of the equine stomach is particularly vulnerable to ulcers because it:

options.label: D
options.text: Contains most of the parietal cells

questions.explanation: The squamous (nonglandular) region lacks mucus and bicarbonate protection, making it vulnerable to acid splash. It does not lack blood supply (A), produce most acid (C), or house most parietal cells (D).

questions.stem: The drug of choice for treating Equine Gastric Ulcer Syndrome (EGUS) is:
questions.explanation: Omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor, is the drug of choice for EGUS. H₂ blockers and sucralfate (A, B, D) are adjuncts but not primary in most cases.

questions.stem: For equine herpesvirus abortion prevention, pregnant mares are commonly vaccinated at which months of gestation?
questions.explanation: Pregnant mares are commonly vaccinated against EHV‑1 at 3, 5, 7, and 9 months of gestation to reduce abortion risk. Other schedules (A, C) or no vaccination (D) are not recommended.

questions.stem: Strangles in horses is caused by:
questions.explanation: Strangles is caused by Streptococcus equi subsp. equi, an obligate pathogen of equids. Zooepidemicus (A) is a commensal/opportunist.

questions.stem: A key step in identifying chronic strangles carriers involves:

options.label: B
options.text: Performing PCR on guttural pouch wash or three consecutive negative nasopharyngeal washes (7 days apart)

questions.explanation: Carrier identification relies on PCR of guttural pouch wash or three consecutive negative nasopharyngeal washes one week apart. Single nasal culture (A), blood or fecal culture (C, D) are insufficient.

questions.stem: The primary route of West Nile virus transmission from horses to humans is:

options.label: B
options.text: Mosquito bites (both species are bitten by infected mosquitoes)

options.label: C
options.text: Aerosol spread from horse to human

questions.explanation: Both horses and humans acquire West Nile virus from mosquito bites; it is not typically transmitted directly from horse to human. Direct contact, aerosols, or feed (A, C, D) are not main routes.

questions.stem: Recurrent Airway Obstruction (RAO) in horses is most analogous to which condition in humans?
questions.explanation: RAO is most analogous to human asthma, with airway hyperreactivity and reversible obstruction. Chronic bronchitis, pneumonia, or TB (A, C, D) are different entities.

questions.stem: A “heave line” along the caudoventral abdomen of a horse is most consistent with:

options.label: A
options.text: An early, mild sign of RAO

options.label: B
options.text: A progressive/severe manifestation of chronic increased expiratory effort in RAO

questions.explanation: A heave line is a sign of progressive/severe RAO due to chronic increased expiratory effort causing hypertrophy of abdominal muscles. It is not an early RAO sign (A), nor a sign of colic or laminitis (C, D).
